Front: Define: burnish (bur-nish)
Back: v. to polish or make shine n. a shiny appearance The store owner's son's only job was to burnish the statues in the window every day. Suffix: -ish (used to form verbs meaning 'to make or cause to be')

Front: Define: buttress (but-riss)
Back: n. a supporting structure v. to support or encourage The parents decided to buttress the after-school programs that were in danger of ending by making donations. Root: butt (from Old French boter, meaning “to strike or thrust”)

Front: Define: equivocate (i-kwiv-uh-keyt)
Back: v. to make vague, unclear statements The mayor equivocated when confronted about his use of public funds. Prefix: equi- (from Latin aequi, meaning “equal”); Root: voc (from Latin vocare, meaning “to call”)

Front: Define: paragon (par-uh-gon)
Back: n. a model of excellence The man was a paragon of virtue who had never stolen so much as a loaf of bread in his life. Prefix: para- (from Greek para, meaning “beside” or “beyond”); Root: gon (from Greek gonia, meaning “angle”)

Front: Define: cacophony (kuh-kof-uh-nee)
Back: n. unpleasant, discordant sounds The orchestra's first attempt to play together was a cacophony of jarring notes. Prefix: caco- (from Greek kakos, meaning “bad”); Root: phon (from Greek phone, meaning “sound”)

Front: Define: mawkish (maw-kish)
Back: adj. overly sentimental to a sickening point The group of graduating seniors was a mawkish sight, crying and taking hundreds of pictures. Suffix: -ish (used to form adjectives, meaning “having the quality of”)

Front: Define: cajole (kuh-djohl)
Back: v. to make someone do something with flattery or promises Mother cajoled her into driving the other children to school, promising to make her favorite dinner. Root: cajol (from French cajoler, meaning “to coax”)

Front: Define: dogmatic (dawg-matt-ik)
Back: adj. rigidly fixed in opinion or expression in an arrogant manner The dogmatic theorist refused to listen to any other possibilities. Root: dogma (from Greek dogma, meaning “opinion” or “belief”); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives, meaning “pertaining to”)

Front: Define: calibrate (kal-ih-brehyt)
Back: v. to check or balance the scale of a measuring device with a standard scale The new thermometer needed to be calibrated before it could be used. Root: caliber (from Arabic qalib, meaning “mold” or “model”); Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs, meaning “to make”)

Front: Define: perdition (per-dish-uhn)
Back: n. a state of final spiritual ruin, loss of soul, damnation n. hell Poor moral choices led Johnny down the road to perdition. Prefix: per- (from Latin, meaning “through” or “thoroughly”); Root: dit (from Latin dare, meaning “to give”); Suffix: -ion (forming nouns, indicating an action or condition)

Front: Define: beseech (bih-seech)
Back: v. to request urgently The dying man beseeched his family to visit him. Prefix: be- (used to form verbs having a sense of 'thoroughly' or 'completely')

Front: Define: canny (can-ee)
Back: adj. careful; shrewd John was a canny negotiator; no matter how bad his bargaining position, he would always come out on top. Suffix: -y (used to form adjectives meaning 'characterized by or inclined to')

Front: Define: seminal (sem-uh-nl)
Back: adj. original and influential The seminal works of the artist developed into a new style of interpretation. Root: semin (from Latin semen, meaning 'seed')

Front: Define: cantankerous (can-tang-kurr-us)
Back: adj. difficult to handle; ill-tempered The worst part about working in customer service was having to deal with irate, cantankerous callers. Suffix: -ous (used to form adjectives meaning 'full of' or 'having the qualities of')

Front: Define: semantic (suh-man-tick)
Back: adj. related to the meaning of words Susan felt that the abortion debate had become too focused on semantic arguments. Root: sem (from Greek sēma, meaning 'sign')

Front: Define: serrate (sare-ate)
Back: adj. having toothed edges (“serrated” is an alternate form of the adj.) Kate used the serrate edge of the knife to cut through the tough meat. Root: serr (from Latin serra, meaning 'saw')

Front: Define: sever (sev-er)
Back: v. to cut off Unfortunately, to prevent the infection from spreading, the doctors had to sever the infected parts of the hand. Root: sever (from Latin separare, meaning 'to separate')

Front: Define: sinuous (sin-you-us)
Back: adj. twisting and winding adj. not direct The sinuous path through the mountains was probably the most dangerous route to take. Root: sinu (from Latin sinus, meaning 'curve' or 'fold')

Front: Define: solicitude (suh-liss-ih-tood)
Back: n. caring about others' well being Though she claims not to have any feelings for Julio, she showed a great deal of solicitude when she learned of his illness. Root: solicit (from Latin sollicitus, meaning 'anxious' or 'concerned')

Front: Define: solidarity (sol-ih-dare-ih-tee)
Back: n. a feeling of camaraderie with others due to shared goals Several townspeople expressed solidarity with the union members by protesting with them. Root: solid (from Latin solidus, meaning 'whole' or 'undivided'); Suffix: -ity (used to form nouns indicating a state or condition)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to polish or make shine n. a shiny appearance Hint: starts with “b”
Back: burnish synonyms: polish, brighten, shine, buff, enhance He spent hours burnishing the silverware until it gleamed. The marble floors had a burnish that reflected the sunlight beautifully.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ancient cathedral was held up by massive stone ________. Hint: Starts with “b” and means “to support or strengthen”.
Back: buttresses buttress (but-riss) n. a supporting structure v. to support or encourage

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make vague, unclear statements Hint: starts with “e”
Back: equivocate synonyms: evade, sidestep, hedge, prevaricate, obscure When asked about his plans, he began to equivocate, avoiding a direct answer.

Front: Fill in the blank: She was considered a ________ of virtue and kindness by everyone who knew her. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “a model of perfection”.
Back: paragon paragon (par-uh-gon) n. a model of excellence

Front: Name the vocab term: n. unpleasant, discordant sounds Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cacophony synonyms: noise, clamor, din, racket, uproar The cacophony of traffic and construction made it impossible to concentrate.

Front: Fill in the blank: The movie's ________ love scenes were so exaggerated that they felt insincere. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “overly sentimental”.
Back: mawkish mawkish (maw-kish) adj. overly sentimental to a sickening point

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make someone do something with flattery or promises Hint: starts with “c”
Back: cajole synonyms: coax, persuade, wheedle, sweet-talk, entice, manipulate He managed to cajole his friend into lending him the car for the weekend.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ stance on the issue left no room for discussion or compromise. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “asserting opinions as absolute truth”.
Back: dogmatic dogmatic (dawg-matt-ik) adj. rigidly fixed in opinion or expression in an arrogant manner

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to check or balance the scale of a measuring device with a standard scale Hint: starts with “c”
Back: calibrate synonyms: align, balance, fix, adjust, standardize, regulate Before starting the experiment, the scientist calibrated the instruments to ensure accuracy.

Front: Fill in the blank: The villain's actions led him down a path of ________, doomed to eternal suffering. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “eternal damnation or ruin”.
Back: perdition perdition (per-dish-uhn) n. a state of final spiritual ruin, loss of soul, damnation n. hell

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to request urgently Hint: starts with “b”
Back: beseech synonyms: beg, appeal, plead, implore, urge, solicit The villagers beseeched the king for help in their time of need.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ negotiation skills helped her secure a great deal on the contract. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “shrewd and careful”.
Back: canny canny (can-ee) adj. careful; shrewd

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. original and influential Hint: starts with “s”
Back: seminal synonyms: landmark, fundamental, fertile, groundbreaking, pioneering, innovative His seminal work in physics changed the way scientists understood the universe.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ old man yelled at anyone who crossed his lawn. Hint: Starts with “c” and means “bad-tempered or argumentative”.
Back: cantankerous cantankerous (can-tang-kurr-us) adj. difficult to handle; ill-tempered

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. related to the meaning of words Hint: starts with “s”
Back: semantic synonyms: linguistic, verbal, meaning-related, lexical, interpretive The argument boiled down to a semantic difference in how they interpreted the contract.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ edge of the knife made it easier to cut through tough materials. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “having a jagged edge”.
Back: serrated serrate (sare-ate) adj. having toothed edges

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to cut off Hint: starts with “s”
Back: sever synonyms: carve, disconnect, break off, cut, split, detach The company had to sever ties with the contractor after the project went over budget.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ path through the mountains made for a challenging hike. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “having many curves”.
Back: sinuous sinuous (sin-you-us) adj. twisting and winding adj. not direct

Front: Name the vocab term: n. caring about others' well being Hint: starts with “s”
Back: solicitude synonyms: consideration, watchfulness, care, concern, attentiveness Her solicitude for her elderly neighbors was evident in the way she checked on them daily.

Front: Fill in the blank: The workers showed ________ during the strike, united in their demands for better conditions. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “unity based on shared goals”.
Back: solidarity solidarity (sol-ih-dare-ih-tee) n. a feeling of camaraderie with others due to shared goals

Front: Define: soluble (sol-yuh-bull)
Back: adj. capable of being dissolved in a liquid adj. capable of being solved Certain medicines are soluble in water so they can be taken with ease. Root: solv (from Latin solvere, meaning “to loosen” or “to dissolve”); Suffix: -able (indicating capability or suitability)

Front: Define: solvent (sol-vunt)
Back: adj. able to meet financial obligations n. a substance that can dissolve other substances To remain solvent, the business was forced to sell its overseas operations. Root: solv (from Latin solvere, meaning “to loosen” or “to dissolve”); Suffix: -ent (indicating an agent or something performing an action)

Front: Define: soporific (sop-uh-riff-ik)
Back: adj. able to cause sleepiness n. a substance that causes sleepiness Bill's new cold medication has soporific side effects that interfere with his ability to drive. Root: sopor (from Latin sopor, meaning “deep sleep”); Suffix: -ific (from Latin -ficus, meaning “making” or “causing”)

Front: Define: emulate (em-yuh-lehyt)
Back: v. to try to imitate or exceed another's actions Nancy wanted to emulate her older sister and so began to study more often. Root: emul (from Latin aemulus, meaning “rivaling” or “imitating”); Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: enamor (ih-nam-er)
Back: v. to make infatuated; to cause to love He was so enamored of her that he thought about her every day. Prefix: en- (from Latin in-, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: amor (from Latin amor, meaning “love”)

Front: Define: endemic (in-dem-ik)
Back: adj. originating in, native to, particular to There are some deadly diseases that are endemic to the tropics. Prefix: en- (from Greek en-, meaning “in”); Root: dem (from Greek demos, meaning “people”); Suffix: -ic (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: endow (in-dow)
Back: v. to give (esp. an inheritance or genetic trait) Christine's mother endowed her with beautiful green eyes. Prefix: en- (from Old French en-, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: dow (from Old English dōn, meaning “to give”)

Front: Define: dour (doo-er)
Back: adj. harsh; gloomy, forbidding adj. stern, humorless The old headmaster never had anything but a dour expression to offer. Root: dour (from Latin durus, meaning “hard” or “stern”)

Front: Define: enervate (in-er-vehyt)
Back: v. to make weaker The heat enervated the soccer players' strength with each passing minute, and by halftime most were in no condition to continue playing. Prefix: e- (from Latin ex-, meaning “out of”); Root: nerv (from Latin nervus, meaning “sinew” or “nerve”); Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: insouciant (in-soo-see-uhnt)
Back: adj. unconcerned, nonchalant, lighthearted Michael's insouciant attitude towards schoolwork led to poor test grades. Prefix: in- (from Latin in-, meaning “not”); Root: souci (from French souci, meaning “care” or “worry”); Suffix: -ant (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: evince (ih-vins)
Back: v. to clearly prove something, to indicate Her choice not to enter into an argument with him evinced her maturity. Prefix: e- (from Latin ex-, meaning “out of”); Root: vinc (from Latin vincere, meaning “to conquer”)

Front: Define: enfranchise (in-fran-chahyz)
Back: v. to give rights of citizenship, esp. the right to vote When women were finally enfranchised, spontaneous celebrations occurred throughout the country. Prefix: en- (from Latin in-, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: franchise (from Old French franc, meaning “free”)

Front: Define: filigree (fil-ih-gree)
Back: n. an ornamental work, esp. delicate and lacelike v. to adorn The wine glass was filigreed with a delicate pattern of grape vines. Root: fil (from Latin filum, meaning “thread”); Root: grée (from Italian grano, meaning “grain”)

Front: Define: engender (in-djen-dur)
Back: v. to cause, to lead to The poor ventilation in the factory engendered health problems amongst the workers. Prefix: en- (from Latin in-, meaning “in” or “into”); Root: gender (from Latin generare, meaning “to produce”)

Front: Define: apocryphal (uh-pok-ruh-fuhl)
Back: adj. of dubious origin; of doubtful authenticity I believe all stories of alien abduction are apocryphal. Prefix: apo- (from Greek apo-, meaning “away” or “off”); Root: cryph (from Greek kryptein, meaning “to hide”); Suffix: -al (forming adjectives)

Front: Define: enmity (en-mih-tee)
Back: n. strong mutual hatred Great enmity has existed between the two tribes for centuries, leading to untold bloodshed. Root: enm (from Latin inimicus, meaning “enemy”); Suffix: -ity (forming nouns)

Front: Define: aesthete (es-theet)
Back: n. one with artistic sensibilities The aesthete was able to knowledgeably interpret the painting. Root: aesth (from Greek aisthesis, meaning “perception” or “sensation”)

Front: Define: estimable (es-tuh-muh-buhl)
Back: adj. formidable, worthy The team knew within the first few minutes that they faced an estimable opponent. Root: estim (from Latin aestimare, meaning “to value” or “to assess”); Suffix: -able (indicating capability or suitability)

Front: Define: revile (ruh-vahyl)
Back: v. to criticize with harsh or abusive language Film critics reviled the studio for gutting the director's artistic vision and replacing it with meaningless action sequences. Prefix: re- (from Latin re-, meaning “again” or “back”); Root: vile (from Latin vilis, meaning “cheap” or “base”)

Front: Define: indefatigable (in-duh-fat-ih-guh-buhl)
Back: adj. incapable of becoming exhausted; tireless; dogged The marathon runner was seemingly indefatigable, keeping up his brisk pace while competitors fell behind one after the other. Prefix: in- (from Latin in-, meaning “not”); Root: defatig (from Latin defatigare, meaning “to tire out”); Suffix: -able (indicating capability or suitability)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. capable of being dissolved in a liquid adj. capable of being solved Hint: starts with “s”
Back: soluble synonyms: dispersable, dissolvable; solvable, liquid, mixable, meltable The sugar is soluble in water.

Front: Fill in the blank: The company is ________ after restructuring. Hint: Starts with “s” and means “able to dissolve substances or pay debts”.
Back: solvent solvent (sol-vunt) adj. able to meet financial obligations n. a substance that can dissolve other substances within itself

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. able to cause sleepiness n. a substance that causes sleepiness Hint: starts with “s”
Back: soporific synonyms: anesthetic, narcotic, sedative, sleep-inducing, tranquilizing, calming The lecture was soporific. The medication had a soporific effect.

Front: Fill in the blank: She tries to ________ her mentor's success. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to imitate in order to equal or excel”.
Back: emulate emulate (em-yuh-lehyt) v. to try to imitate or exceed another's actions

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make infatuated; to cause to love Hint: starts with “e”
Back: enamor synonyms: fascinate, captivate, infatuate, allure, enchant He was enamored with her charm.

Front: Fill in the blank: This species is ________ to the island. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “native or restricted to an area”.
Back: endemic endemic (in-dem-ik) adj. originating in, native to, particular to

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to give (esp. an inheritance or genetic trait) Hint: starts with “e”
Back: endow synonyms: provide, impart, bestow, grant, furnish Her grandmother endowed her with a trust fund.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ demeanor intimidated the staff. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “stern and gloomy”.
Back: dour dour (doo-er) adj. harsh; gloomy, forbidding adj. stern, humorless

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make weaker Hint: starts with “e”
Back: enervate synonyms: tire, exhaust, debilitate, sap, weaken The heat enervated the athletes.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ attitude was refreshing. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “carefree and unconcerned”.
Back: insouciant insouciant (in-soo-see-uhnt) adj. unconcerned, nonchalant, lighthearted

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to clearly prove something, to indicate Hint: starts with “e”
Back: evince synonyms: declare, demonstrate, reveal, show, manifest He evinced great interest in the project.

Front: Fill in the blank: Women were ________ in the early 20th century. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “given the right to vote”.
Back: enfranchised enfranchise (in-fran-chahyz) v. to give rights of citizenship, esp. the right to vote

Front: Name the vocab term: n. an ornamental work, esp. delicate and lacelike v. to adorn Hint: starts with “f”
Back: filigree synonyms: decoration, ornamentation; decorate, embellishment, lacework The jewelry was adorned with gold filigree. She filigreed the edges of her project.

Front: Fill in the blank: The policy ________ debate. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “caused or gave rise to”.
Back: engendered engender (in-djen-dur) v. to cause, to lead to

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. of dubious origin; of doubtful authenticity Hint: starts with “a”
Back: apocryphal synonyms: fictitious, doubtful, unverified, questionable, spurious The story of his victory seems apocryphal.

Front: Fill in the blank: There was clear ________ between the rivals. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “hostile opposition or hatred”.
Back: enmity enmity (en-mih-tee) n. strong mutual hatred

Front: Name the vocab term: n. one with artistic sensibilities Hint: starts with “a”
Back: aesthete synonyms: artist, connoisseur, art lover, creative, visionary As an aesthete, she appreciated fine art.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ work earned her many accolades. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “worthy of respect”.
Back: estimable estimable (es-tuh-muh-buhl) adj. formidable, worthy

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to criticize with harsh or abusive language Hint: starts with “r”
Back: revile synonyms: scold, criticize, abuse, denounce, vilify, berate The critics reviled the film for its poor acting.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ energy amazed everyone. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “persisting tirelessly”.
Back: indefatigable indefatigable (in-duh-fat-ih-guh-buhl) adj. incapable of becoming exhausted; tireless; dogged

Front: Define: ensemble (on-som-bul)
Back: n. a whole group formed by separate parts The band was an ensemble of classical violinists, guitarists, and a jazz pianist. Prefix: en- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “into”), Root: semble (from Latin simulare, meaning “to make like” or “to imitate”)

Front: Define: effervescent (eff-er-vess-uhnt)
Back: adj. emitting small bubbles adj. lively, showing high spirits, vivacious Stacy's effervescent mind captivated everyone she met. Prefix: ef- (variant of ex-, meaning “out”), Root: ferv (from Latin fervēre, meaning “to boil”), Suffix: -escent (indicating the process of becoming)

Front: Define: enthrall (in-thrawl)
Back: v. to captivate v. to enslave The singer's voice enthralled the judges, who immediately awarded her first place in the contest. Prefix: en- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “into”), Root: thrall (from Old English þræll, meaning “slave” or “servant”)

Front: Define: entreat (in-treet)
Back: v. to plead The rejected boy entreated the girl to give him a second chance. Prefix: en- (from Latin in, meaning “in” or “into”), Root: treat (from Latin tractare, meaning “to handle” or “to manage”)

Front: Define: extirpate (ek-ster-peyt)
Back: v. to destroy, annihilate totally v. to cut out by the roots Modern thinkers have proposed to extirpate religion from all political discourse. Prefix: ex- (meaning “out” or “away”), Root: stirp (from Latin stirps, meaning “root” or “stock”)

Front: Define: enumerate (ih-new-muh-rate)
Back: v. to list items individually Shocked by her decision, I asked her to enumerate her reasons for firing him. Prefix: e- (variant of ex-, meaning “out”), Root: numer (from Latin numerus, meaning “number”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: internecine (in-ter-neh-seen)
Back: adj. mutually destructive adj. characterized by bloodshed and carnage adj. relating to intra-group struggle That country's internecine struggle was only put to rest after many innocent people lost their lives. Prefix: inter- (meaning “between” or “among”), Root: nec (from Latin necare, meaning “to kill”)

Front: Define: ephemeral (uh-fem-er-ul)
Back: adj. lasting only a short while Our joy at being let out for the weekend was only ephemeral, for we soon realized that we had a lot of studying to do for Monday. Prefix: ep- (variant of epi-, meaning “upon” or “close to”), Root: hemer (from Greek hēmera, meaning “day”)

Front: Define: variegated (vair-ee-uh-gehyt-id)
Back: adj. multicolored adj. varied The variegated leaves were a sure sign that autumn had arrived. Root: vari (from Latin varius, meaning “varied”), Suffix: -egate (related to the Latin agere, meaning “to do” or “to make”)

Front: Define: venerate (ven-uh-rehyt)
Back: v. to respect deeply and honor The children venerated their grandfather and sought not to disappoint him. Root: vener (from Latin venerari, meaning “to worship”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: veracity (vur-rass-ih-tee)
Back: n. truthfulness In order to have her article published, Susan needed to prove the veracity of her claims. Root: ver (from Latin verus, meaning “true”), Suffix: -acity (indicating a quality or state)

Front: Define: verbiage (ver-bee-idge)
Back: n. an overabundance of words n. one's manner of speaking The elderly speaker's verbiage tended toward the formal. Root: verb (from Latin verbum, meaning “word”), Suffix: -age (indicating an action or process)

Front: Define: vestige (ves-tidge)
Back: n. a small remnant That abandoned well is a vestige of the manor that once stood here. Root: vestig (from Latin vestigium, meaning “footprint” or “trace”)

Front: Define: vex (vex)
Back: v. to annoy or bother v. to confound v. to talk about extensively It was when they were allowed to horse around the house that the children vexed her the most. Root: vex (from Latin vexare, meaning “to shake” or “to annoy”)

Front: Define: vigilant (vidge-ih-lunt)
Back: adj. watchful Our new dog is very vigilant when it comes to guarding the house. Root: vigil (from Latin vigil, meaning “awake” or “watchful”), Suffix: -ant (indicating an agent or something performing an action)

Front: Define: vigor (vig-er)
Back: n. energy, vitality n. strength; forcefulness After she broke her hip dancing, Kate realized that she had lost the youthful vigor she once had. Root: vigor (from Latin vigere, meaning “to be lively” or “to thrive”)

Front: Define: virtuoso (vur-chew-owe-so)
Back: n. a highly-skilled artist Even at a young age, it was clear that Beethoven was a virtuoso in the making. Root: virt (from Latin virtus, meaning “excellence” or “virtue”), Suffix: -oso (used in Italian to denote a person with a particular skill)

Front: Define: viscous (viss-kuss)
Back: adj. thick and syrup-like They slathered a viscous glue over the pieces to make sure they would stick. Root: visc (from Latin viscum, meaning “birdlime” or “sticky substance”), Suffix: -ous (indicating possessing or full of)

Front: Define: vituperate (vahy-too-puh-rehyt)
Back: v. to scold The old man vituperated the neighborhood boys who were trespassing on his lawn. Root: vituper (from Latin vituperare, meaning “to blame” or “to scold”), Suffix: -ate (used to form verbs)

Front: Define: vivacious (vih-vey-shuss)
Back: adj. energetic; full of life At ninety years old, Melinda was known for being particularly vivacious for her age. Root: viv (from Latin vivere, meaning “to live”), Suffix: -acious (indicating a tendency or inclination)

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a whole group formed by separate parts Hint: starts with “e”
Back: ensemble synonyms: band, collection, organization, group, assembly, team The ensemble performed flawlessly, each musician contributing to the harmonious piece.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ personality lit up the room. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “bubbly or lively”.
Back: effervescent effervescent (eff-er-vess-uhnt) adj. emitting small bubbles adj. lively, showing high spirits, vivacious

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to captivate v. to enslave Hint: starts with 'e'
Back: enthrall synonyms: absorb, enrapture, beckon, beguile, charm, fascinate, grip The magician's tricks enthralled the audience.

Front: Fill in the blank: She ________ him to stay for the evening. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “begged or pleaded earnestly”.
Back: entreated entreat (in-treet) v. to plead

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to destroy, annihilate totally v. to cut out by the roots Hint: starts with “e”
Back: extirpate synonyms: destroy, annihilate; remove, uproot, eradicate, eliminate, abolish They worked to extirpate the invasive species.

Front: Fill in the blank: She ________ the reasons for her decision. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “listed one by one”.
Back: enumerated enumerate (ih-new-muh-rate) v. to list items one by one

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. mutually destructive adj. characterized by bloodshed and carnage adj. relating to intra-group struggle Hint: starts with “i”
Back: internecine synonyms: civil, fratricidal, deadly, bloody, catastrophic, self-destructive, destructive The internecine conflict devastated the entire region.

Front: Fill in the blank: The sunset's beauty was ________ but unforgettable. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “lasting a very short time”.
Back: ephemeral ephemeral (uh-fem-er-ul) adj. lasting a very short time

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. appearing to have different colors adj. varied Hint: starts with “v”
Back: variegated synonyms: diverse, kaleidoscopic, multicolored, assorted, mixed The artist used a variegated palette for the mural.

Front: Fill in the blank: They ________ their elders with great ceremony. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “regarded with deep respect”.
Back: venerated venerate (ven-uh-rehyt) v. to respect deeply and honor

Front: Name the vocab term: n. truthfulness Hint: starts with “v”
Back: veracity synonyms: certainty, truth, fact, accuracy, honesty, integrity His veracity was never in question.

Front: Fill in the blank: The report was filled with unnecessary ________. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “excessive or unnecessary words”.
Back: verbiage verbiage (ver-bee-idge) n. an overabundance of words n. one's manner of speaking

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a small remnant Hint: starts with “v”
Back: vestige synonyms: remainder, hint, trace, fragment, relic Only a vestige of the ancient building remained.

Front: Fill in the blank: His constant questions began to ________ her. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “to annoy or frustrate”.
Back: vex vex (vex) v. to annoy or bother v. to confound v. to talk about extensively

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. watchful Hint: starts with “v”
Back: vigilant synonyms: attentive, aware, on the lookout, alert, observant, cautious The security guard remained vigilant throughout the night.

Front: Fill in the blank: She tackled the project with great ________. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “physical strength or energy”.
Back: vigor vigor (vig-er) n. energy, vitality n. strength; forcefulness

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a highly-skilled artist Hint: starts with “v”
Back: virtuoso synonyms: ace, artist, professional, maestro, genius, expert The pianist was a virtuoso, admired worldwide.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ honey slowly dripped from the spoon. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “thick and sticky”.
Back: viscous viscous (viss-kuss) adj. thick and syrup-like

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to scold Hint: starts with “v”
Back: vituperate synonyms: abuse, berate, yell at, criticize, reprimand, condemn The coach began to vituperate the team for their poor performance.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ spirit made her the life of the party. Hint: Starts with “v” and means “lively and spirited”.
Back: vivacious vivacious (vih-vey-shuss) adj. energetic; full of life

Front: Define: meticulous (muh-tick-yuh-luss)
Back: adj. paying great attention to detail He was a meticulous sculptor, sometimes spending hours perfecting a single fingernail on one of his figures. Root: metus (from Latin, meaning “fear” or “anxiety”)

Front: Define: mimicry (mim-ih-kree)
Back: n. a close imitation of something else Mimicry is common in the animal kingdom, such as when harmless species assume the aspect of poisonous ones to avoid being eaten. Root: mim (from Greek mimos, meaning “imitator” or “actor”)

Front: Define: minuet (min-you-et)
Back: n. a slow, stately, pattern dance in 3/4 time n. the music to accompany the dance of the same name A minuet is always danced with three beats per measure. Root: minu (from Latin minutus, meaning “small” or “minute”)

Front: Define: minute (my-newt)
Back: adj. tiny adj. attentive to the smallest details The chances of such a slow horse actually winning the race are minute. Root: minu (from Latin minutus, meaning “small” or “minute”)

Front: Define: mirth (murth)
Back: n. glee; joy The house was always full of happy laughter and other signs of mirth. Root: mirth (from Old English myrgth, meaning “joy” or “pleasure”)

Front: Define: dissipated (dis-uh-pey-tid)
Back: adj. indulging in excessive devotion to pleasure; debauched, dissolute; wasted, squandered; to cause to disappear, disperse His life quickly became dissipated and unstructured after he won the lottery. Prefix: dis- (from Latin, meaning “apart” or “away”), Root: sip (from Latin supare, meaning “to throw”)

Front: Define: misanthrope (miss-un-throwp)
Back: n. hater of humanity The old man was a notorious misanthrope who loathed even his own children. Prefix: mis- (from Greek, meaning “hate”), Root: anthrop (from Greek anthropos, meaning “human”)

Front: Define: invidious (in-vid-ee-uhs)
Back: adj. offensive, provoking resentment or ill-will The teacher's invidious practice of playing favorites led to several parent conferences. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning “in” or “on”), Root: vid (from Latin videre, meaning “to see”)

Front: Define: misconstrue (miss-kun-strew)
Back: v. to misunderstand Eva has a habit of misconstruing compliments, reading amorous designs into the most innocent remarks. Prefix: mis- (from Old English, meaning “wrong” or “badly”), Root: stru (from Latin struere, meaning “to build” or “to arrange”)

Front: Define: remit (rih-mit)
Back: v. to transmit payment v. to refrain from exacting v. to pardon v. to desist, postpone or give up The transaction was completed after the buyer remitted the money. Prefix: re- (from Latin, meaning “back” or “again”), Root: mit (from Latin mittere, meaning “to send”)

Front: Define: mitigate (mit-ih-gate)
Back: v. to make smaller or less problematic The hurricane's effect was mitigated by the quick response from the national guard. Root: miti (from Latin mitis, meaning “soft” or “gentle”), Suffix: -gate (from Latin agere, meaning “to drive” or “to lead”)

Front: Define: opprobrium (uh-proh-bree-uhm)
Back: n. the disgrace felt by someone who has acted in an outrageously shameful manner Oedipus Rex experienced great opprobrium after learning the true extent of his crimes. Root: opprobri (from Latin opprobrum, meaning “disgrace” or “reproach”)

Front: Define: mollify (mohl-ih-fahy)
Back: v. to decrease the strength of, pacify, placate v. to make softer, less severe His rage was mollified by his wife's soothing words. Root: moll (from Latin mollis, meaning “soft”), Suffix: -fy (from Latin facere, meaning “to make”)

Front: Define: momentum (moh-men-tum)
Back: n. strength built up by continued movement or development The protest gained momentum as it passed through the city and gained new supporters. Root: moment (from Latin momentum, meaning “movement” or “motion”)

Front: Define: prodigious (pruh-didj-us)
Back: adj. having great power or size adj. extreme The building of the new dam is a prodigious project requiring thousands of men and millions of dollars. Root: prodigi (from Latin prodigium, meaning “omen” or “portent”), Suffix: -ous (from Latin, meaning “full of”)

Front: Define: asperity (uh-sper-ih-tee)
Back: n. severity, rigor n. acrimony, irritability The asperity of a northern winter can lead to depression. Root: asper (from Latin asper, meaning “rough” or “harsh”), Suffix: -ity (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: profligate (prof-lih-git)
Back: adj. immoral adj. recklessly extravagant She criticized her spoiled son for his profligate lifestyle. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning “forward” or “forth”), Root: flig (from Latin fligere, meaning “to strike”)

Front: Define profuse (pruh-fewss)
Back: adj. abundant adj. freely giving or spending Horrified by the consequences of her actions, Joyce offered profuse apologies to her friends. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning “forward” or “forth”), Root: fus (from Latin fundere, meaning “to pour”)

Front: Define: hapless (hap-liss)
Back: adj. unlucky, unfortunate, luckless The hapless, accident-prone child managed to break his leg for the third time. Root: hap (from Old Norse happ, meaning “luck” or “chance”), Suffix: -less (from Old English, meaning “without”)

Front: Define: prognostic (prog-noss-tick)
Back: n. a prediction adj. indicating future events Climate scientists presented a chilling prognostic of what will happen to our planet in the near future. Prefix: pro- (from Greek, meaning “before”), Root: gnostic (from Greek gnosis, meaning “knowledge”)

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. paying great attention to detail Hint: starts with “m”
Back: meticulous synonyms: perfectionist, painstaking, thorough, precise, careful She was meticulous in her research, ensuring no errors were made.

Front: Fill in the blank: The comedian's ________ of celebrities had everyone laughing. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “the act of imitating”.
Back: mimicry mimicry (mim-ih-kree) n. a close imitation of something else

Front: Name the vocab term: n. a slow, stately, pattern dance in 3/4 time n. the music to accompany the dance of the same name Hint: starts with “m”
Back: minuet synonyms: dance, waltz; music, piece, suite, melody, rhythm They danced a graceful minuet at the formal ball. The orchestra played a classical minuet to set the mood.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ observations caught every flaw in the design. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “extremely small”.
Back: minute minute (my-newt) adj. tiny adj. attentive to the smallest details

Front: Name the vocab term: n. glee; joy Hint: starts with “m”
Back: mirth synonyms: cheer, amusement, happiness, delight, joyfulness The party was filled with mirth and laughter.

Front: Fill in the blank: His ________ lifestyle left him broke and alone. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “overindulging in pleasures”.
Back: dissipated dissipated (dis-uh-pey-tid) adj. devoted to the pursuit of pleasure; hedonistic

Front: Name the vocab term: n. hater of humanity Hint: starts with “m”
Back: misanthrope synonyms: cynic, curmudgeon, recluse, hermit, introvert The old misanthrope avoided social interactions at all costs.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her ________ comments stirred up anger among her colleagues. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “likely to cause resentment”.
Back: invidious invidious (in-vid-ee-uhs) adj. offensive, provoke resentment or ill-will

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to misunderstand Hint: starts with “m”
Back: misconstrue synonyms: distort, mistake, misread, misinterpret, misconceive, confuse He misconstrued her friendly gesture as romantic interest.

Front: Fill in the blank: The court decided to ________ her sentence. Hint: Starts with “r” and means “to cancel or send payment”.
Back: remit remit (rih-mit) v. to transmit payment v. to refrain from exacting v. to pardon v. to desist, postpone or give up

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to make smaller or less problematic Hint: starts with “m”
Back: mitigate synonyms: diminish, lighten, alleviate, reduce, lessen The government tried to mitigate the impact of the economic downturn.

Front: Fill in the blank: The public ________ over his misconduct led to his resignation. Hint: Starts with “o” and means “public disgrace or shame”.
Back: opprobrium opprobrium (uh-proh-bree-uhm) n. the disgrace felt by someone who has acted in an outrageously shameful manner, contempt

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to decrease the strength of v. to make softer Hint: starts with “m”
Back: mollify synonyms: disarm, smooth over, soften, calm, appease, soothe She tried to mollify his anger with a sincere apology. The doctor mollified the patient's concerns with comforting words.

Front: Fill in the blank: The project gained ________ after the initial success. Hint: Starts with “m” and means “driving force gained by motion”.
Back: momentum momentum (moh-men-tum) n. strength built up by continued movement or development

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. having great power or size adj. extreme Hint: starts with “p”
Back: prodigious synonyms: massive, colossal, monumental, extraordinary, enormous, immense, vast The prodigious mountain loomed over the valley. Her prodigious talent earned her widespread recognition.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ in his voice made it clear he was angry. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “harshness of tone or manner”.
Back: asperity asperity (uh-sper-ih-tee) n. severity, rigor n. acrimony, irritability

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. immoral adj. recklessly extravagant Hint: starts with “p”
Back: profligate synonyms: corrupt, degenerate; immoderate, lavish, wasteful, extravagant, dissipated His profligate behavior led to his downfall. She lived a profligate lifestyle, spending money on luxury items.

Front: Fill in the blank: The garden was ________ with blooming flowers. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “abundant or excessive”.
Back: profuse profuse (pruh-fewss) adj. abundant adj. freely giving or spending

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. unlucky, unfortunate, luckless Hint: starts with “h”
Back: hapless synonyms: luckless, jinxed, unfortunate, ill-fated, doomed The hapless traveler missed his flight and lost his luggage.

Front: Fill in the blank: The patient's symptoms were ________ of a more serious condition. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “serving to predict a future event”.
Back: prognostic prognostic (prog-noss-tick) n. a prediction adj. indicating future events

Front: Define: proliferate (pruh-lif-er-ehyt)
Back: v. to grow and spread quickly Tensions in the area proliferated after the civilian casualties. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning 'forward' or 'forth'); Root: life (from Latin lifer, meaning 'life')

Front: Define: puissant (pyoo-uh-suhnt)
Back: adj. powerful, mighty A puissant leader can secure the success of an entire team. Root: potent (from Latin potens, meaning 'powerful')

Front: Define: prone (prone)
Back: adj. lying face or front downward adj. tending to behave or act a certain way Lucy was prone to cheat on tests, so the teachers placed her in a separate room. Root: pronus (from Latin, meaning 'leaning forward')

Front: Define: propitiate (proh-pish-ee-ehyt)
Back: v. to appease The custom was to propitiate the angry gods with a sacrifice. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning 'for' or 'in favor of'); Root: pet (from Latin petere, meaning 'to seek')

Front: Define: ineffable (in-eff-uh-buhl)
Back: adj. incapable of being described in words After a long day you can find ineffable pleasure in a hot bath. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning 'not'); Root: fari (from Latin, meaning 'to speak'); Suffix: -able (from Latin, meaning 'capable of')

Front: Define: propitious (pruh-pish-us)
Back: adj. favorable The rainy weather was not propitious for the picnic they had planned. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning 'for' or 'in favor of'); Root: pet (from Latin petere, meaning 'to seek'); Suffix: -ous (from Latin, meaning 'full of')

Front: Define: propound (pruh-pound)
Back: v. to propose or offer for consideration To make her point about the dangers of sunburns, Kate _propound_ed various theories about skin cancer and its links to ultraviolet radiation. Prefix: pro- (from Latin, meaning 'forward'); Root: ponere (from Latin, meaning 'to place' or 'to set')

Front: Define: propriety (pruh-pry-ih-tee)
Back: n. proper behavior A model housewife, Mary valued propriety and manners over everything else. Root: proprius (from Latin, meaning 'one's own' or 'proper'); Suffix: -ity (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Define: precipitate (prih-sip-ih-teyt)
Back: adj. acting with haste or on impulse v. to cause or hasten an event The officer took precipitate action and wound up making the situation even worse. Prefix: pre- (from Latin, meaning 'before'); Root: caput (from Latin, meaning 'head')

Front: Define: prosaic (pro-zay-ik)
Back: adj. common; unimaginative Kate's realistic paintings of household objects were criticized as being too prosaic. Root: prosa (from Latin, meaning 'straightforward' or 'direct'); Suffix: -ic (from Latin, meaning 'pertaining to')

Front: Define: prudent (proo-dent)
Back: adj. practical; careful His assistant was particularly prudent when it came to keeping the company's secrets. Root: providere (from Latin, meaning 'to foresee'); Suffix: -ent (from Latin, indicating an agent or something performing an action)

Front: Define: advert (ad-vurt)
Back: v. to call or direct attention towards As soon as Jim saw the unsafe guardrail, he adverted everyone to the problem. Prefix: ad- (from Latin, meaning 'to' or 'toward'); Root: vertere (from Latin, meaning 'to turn')

Front: Define: excoriate (ik-skawr-ee-eyt)
Back: v. to condemn scathingly After the student's repetitive acts of bullying, the principal _excoriate_d him. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning 'out of' or 'from'); Root: corium (from Latin, meaning 'skin' or 'hide')

Front: Define: insipid (in-sip-id)
Back: adj. bland, trite The film's insipid plot, like that of hundreds of others, centered on American agents thwarting a Russian spy ring. Prefix: in- (from Latin, meaning 'not'); Root: sapidus (from Latin, meaning 'tasty' or 'savory')

Front: Define: sublimate (suhb-luh-meyt)
Back: v. to change state of matter between solid and gaseous form without passing through a liquid stage v. to modify the expression of an instinctual impulse in a socially acceptable manner Dry ice sublimates directly from its solid ice form to the gas you see rising off of it. Prefix: sub- (from Latin, meaning 'under' or 'up to'); Root: limen (from Latin, meaning 'threshold')

Front: Define: expatiate (ik-spey-shee-eyt)
Back: v. to discuss or write about at great length Margie expatiated about her misfortunes until early in the morning. Prefix: ex- (from Latin, meaning 'out of'); Root: spatium (from Latin, meaning 'space' or 'room')

Front: Define: precipitous (prih-sip-ih-tuhs)
Back: adj. dangerously high or steep adj. done hastily and without care The economy suffered a precipitous decline in exports. Prefix: pre- (from Latin, meaning 'before'); Root: caput (from Latin, meaning 'head'); Suffix: -ous (from Latin, meaning 'full of')

Front: Define: necromancy (nek-ruh-man-see)
Back: n. the practice of communicating with the spirits of the dead n. black magic, black arts, or sorcery Aunt Pam claimed that necromancy was a way you could speak to your ancestors. Root: necro- (from Greek nekros, meaning 'dead'); Root: mancy (from Greek manteia, meaning 'divination')

Front: Define: truculent (truhk-yuh-luhnt)
Back: adj. cruel, ferocious, savage, brutal The truculent dictator did not care about the well-being of his people. Root: trux (from Latin, meaning 'fierce' or 'savage'); Suffix: -ulent (from Latin, meaning 'full of')

Front: Define: depravity (dih-prav-ih-tee)
Back: n. moral corruption or degradation The various depravities of modern society include an unhealthy obsession with the lives and deaths of celebrities. Prefix: de- (from Latin, meaning 'down' or 'away'); Root: pravus (from Latin, meaning 'crooked' or 'perverse'); Suffix: -ity (from Latin, indicating a state or condition)

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to grow and spread quickly Hint: starts with “p”
Back: proliferate synonyms: expand, develop, increase, multiply, escalate Rumors about the incident began to proliferate online.

Front: Fill in the blank: The king was a ________ ruler, feared by his enemies. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “powerful or mighty”.
Back: puissant puissant (pyoo-uh-suhnt) adj. powerful, mighty

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. lying face or front downward adj. tending to behave or act a certain way Hint: starts with “p”
Back: prone synonyms: face down, flat, horizontal; likely, susceptible, vulnerable, inclined He lay prone on the grass, staring at the sky. She is prone to anxiety in stressful situations.

Front: Fill in the blank: He tried to ________ the angry crowd with a public apology. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “to appease or win favor”.
Back: propitiate propitiate (proh-pish-ee-ehyt) v. to appease

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. incapable of being described in words Hint: starts with “i”
Back: ineffable synonyms: beyond words, indescribable, unutterable, sublime, inexpressible The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

Front: Fill in the blank: The clear skies were a ________ sign for the outdoor event. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “favorable or promising”.
Back: propitious propitious (pruh-pish-us) adj. favorable

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to propose or offer for consideration Hint: starts with “p”
Back: propound synonyms: counsel, advise, set forth, present, suggest, introduce She propounded a new solution to the problem.

Front: Fill in the blank: He always acted with ________ during formal meetings. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “conformity to accepted behavior”.
Back: propriety propriety (pruh-pry-ih-tee) n. proper behavior

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. acting with haste or on impulse v. to cause or hasten an event Hint: starts with “p”
Back: precipitate synonyms: expedite, advance, hasten, provoke, trigger His precipitate decision led to unforeseen consequences. The sudden rain precipitated a halt to the outdoor concert.

Front: Fill in the blank: Her speech was filled with ________ statements, lacking creativity. Hint: Starts with “p” and means “lacking imagination; dull”.
Back: prosaic prosaic (pro-zay-ik) adj. common; unimaginative

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. practical; careful Hint: starts with “p”
Back: prudent synonyms: canny, sagacious, wise, judicious, sensible It was a prudent decision to save money for emergencies.

Front: Fill in the blank: The article ________ to the growing environmental issues. Hint: Starts with “a” and means “called attention to”.
Back: adverted advert (ad-vurt) v. to call or direct attention towards

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to condemn scathingly Hint: starts with “e”
Back: excoriate synonyms: berate, scathe, chastise, denounce, revile, attack The critics excoriated the movie for its poor script.

Front: Fill in the blank: The ________ conversation bored everyone at the table. Hint: Starts with “i” and means “lacking flavor or interest”.
Back: insipid insipid (in-sip-id) adj. bland, trite

Front: Name the vocab term: v. to change state of matter between solid and gaseous form without passing through a liquid stage v. to modify the expression of an instinctual impulse in a socially acceptable manner Hint: starts with “s”
Back: sublimate synonyms: refine, transfer, redirect, transform, channel, convert Dry ice sublimates directly into gas. He sublimated his anger into intense physical exercise.

Front: Fill in the blank: She loved to ________ on her travels through Europe. Hint: Starts with “e” and means “to speak or write at length”.
Back: expatiate expatiate (ik-spey-shee-eyt) v. to discuss or write about at great length

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. dangerously high or steep adj. done hastily and without care Hint: starts with “p”
Back: precipitous synonyms: steep, arduous, high; impulsive, abrupt, sudden, reckless The hikers carefully navigated the precipitous cliffs. His precipitous actions led to unfortunate consequences.

Front: Fill in the blank: The villagers feared the old woman practiced ________. Hint: Starts with “n” and means “magic involving communication with the dead”.
Back: necromancy necromancy (nek-ruh-man-see) n. the practice of allegedly communicating with the spirits of the dead n. black magic, black arts, or sorcery

Front: Name the vocab term: adj. cruel, ferocious, savage, brutal Hint: starts with “t”
Back: truculent synonyms: abusive, aggressive, hostile, fierce, belligerent, combative His truculent attitude made him difficult to work with.

Front: Fill in the blank: The dictator's ________ shocked the entire nation. Hint: Starts with “d” and means “moral corruption”.
Back: depravity depravity (dih-prav-ih-tee) n. moral corruption or degradation
